cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mass spectrometry is applied to a sample when identifying and quantifying drugs or toxins.
Forensic scientists collect and catalog evidence.
remarks: Cataloging is treated as part of the collection/handling relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Forensic scientists investigate the crime scene by meticulously documenting its details.
Forensic scientists collect all relevant evidence as part of their work.
Forensic scientists solve complex investigative puzzles as part of their work.
Forensic scientists uncover hidden clues during investigations.
Hidden clues may be crucial for a case.
Forensic scientists uncover the truth behind challenging forensic cases.

qualifiers.CausalHint: By combining scientific principles with investigative techniques

args.canonical_rel_desc: Links an analytical technique to the sample or material to which it is applied.
args.justification: This relation instance connects the analytical technique (mass spectrometry) with the sample it is used on; a generic predicate 'applied_to' accurately captures this procedural application without overspecifying context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an agent gathers or collects forensic evidence.
args.justification: Both relations describe forensic scientists gathering evidence; direction and semantics are identical (agent → evidence collection), so they should share the same canonical predicate 'collects'.
args.remark: Cataloging is treated as part of the broader evidence collection/handling activity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Denotes that an investigator examines or investigates a crime scene or context.
args.justification: The relation links forensic scientists to a crime scene they are examining; 'investigates' succinctly captures this investigative activity.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an investigator resolves or solves complex investigative problems or puzzles.
args.justification: This relation connects forensic scientists to complex investigative puzzles they resolve; 'solves' is an appropriate, general predicate for this reasoning task.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an investigator identifies or uncovers previously unknown or hidden clues.
args.justification: The instance describes forensic scientists uncovering hidden clues; 'discovers' captures the act of revealing previously unknown investigative elements.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Expresses that one element (e.g., a clue) is crucial or highly important for the progress or outcome of a case.
args.justification: The description states that hidden clues may be crucial for a case; the predicate 'is_critical_for' cleanly encodes this importance relation from clue to case.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an investigator reveals or uncovers the truth about a forensic case or issue.
args.justification: The relation links forensic scientists to the truth behind challenging cases that they reveal; 'uncovers_truth_about' captures this outcome-focused investigative action with appropriate direction.
This relation models the application of an analytical technique (mass spectrometry) to a sample, fitting a class that groups uses of analytical methods on materials or samples.
Both relations concern forensic scientists collecting and handling evidence at or related to a crime scene; they belong in a shared class for evidence acquisition and handling activities.
The relation captures the core investigative activity of examining a crime scene; a specific class for investigation activities is appropriate.

Both relations involve higher-level reasoning tasks by forensic scientists (solving investigative puzzles and discovering hidden clues); grouping them in a class for reasoning and inferential investigative actions is coherent.
This relation describes the importance of hidden clues for a case outcome; a class capturing the significance or probative value of evidence elements is appropriate.
The relation expresses an outcome of investigative work (uncovering the truth about cases); a class for outcome-level investigative relations fits this semantics.
The relation focuses on how an analytical technique is used/applied to a sample, aligning best with a broad usage/application dimension.
These relations all describe actions performed by agents (forensic scientists) on evidence, scenes, puzzles, clues, or cases; they are best grouped under an agency/agent-action dimension.

The relation states that hidden clues may be crucial for a case, implying that the presence or nature of clues causally or critically affects the case outcome; this fits a causal/importance dimension.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Links an analytical technique to the sample or material to which it is applied.
